{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3525804,"name":"sanddrag","username":"sanddrag","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/c68b51/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-13T06:39:01.113Z","cooked":"

I saw this announcement today that Autodesk is pulling the plug on HSMWorks.

Autodesk Community ‚Äì 3 Feb 25

HSMWorks End Of Life March 25th, 2028

HSMWorks End Of Life March 25th, 2028

What a bummer. Of course the simple answer is switch to Fusion, but is that really so smart? Autodesk has time and again discontinued great software that people love, and/or moved or removed features from certain licensing tiers. So I‚Äôm wondering, what are the other options for CAM software these days? Something that we own forever would be cool.

I know Solidworks comes with CAM. Anyone used it? When I looked at it years ago it seemed clunky to use.

Anyone try CAM Workbench in FreeCAD? How is it these days? I‚Äôve heard they‚Äôve made a ton of improvements lately.

Cut2D looks like a nice option. Does it do all the things I would want to do?

I thought there was a program called SheetCAM that used to do 2.5D milling, but I‚Äôm not finding it these days.

I think Onshape is working on CAM but I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs coming to the free or education tiers. Anyone have more info?

Years ago before HSM and Fusion I used OneCNC. Aside from a couple post processor issues, it was a pretty nice software. But, HSM is nicer.

Is CamBam still a thing?

MasterCAM I think is too much of a learning curve, and the licensing is not as accessible.

So, what are you all using other than HSM and Fusion?

sanddrag:

I think Onshape is working on CAM but I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs coming to the free or education tiers. Anyone have more info?

Under discussion on that.

Onshape CAM Studio Update in Regards to FRC Onshape
As part of Onshape Release 1.193, Onshape CAM Studio was released in a Beta status and is available to Professional and Pro Enterprise users. This is a large milestone for Onshape, but it‚Äôs understandable if there‚Äôs disappointment that it‚Äôs not currently available on Education plans. Why Only Pro Plans? Onshape CAM Studio is being released as a public beta to only these plans so we can scale appropriately and ensure that any issues are handled before we expand it to a larger userbase. What‚Äôs ‚Ä¶

sanddrag:

Cut2D looks like a nice option. Does it do all the things I would want to do?

We really like Cut2D for router parts. Had to give up HSMworks when we went to Onshape, and I miss it occasionally for the really nice renders, but Cut2D is a better feature set for introductory part cutting and student to student teaching.

I wouldn‚Äôt use Cut2D for a 3D part. We don‚Äôt have 3D milling capabilities, so it hasn‚Äôt come up, but I‚Äôm curious what folks use.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2025-02-13T06:51:00.811Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":337,"readers_count":336,"score":82.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":491502,"topic_slug":"hsmworks-is-ending-alternatives","display_username":"s-neff","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":28019,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/hsmworks-is-ending-alternatives/491502/3","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3527231,"name":"usbcd36","username":"usbcd36","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/usbcd36/{size}/2444_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-14T18:13:15.190Z","cooked":"

We use V-Carve, which is Cut2D plus more features, including crude 3D. I find it to be a very mixed bag. But I‚Äôve also been using it for 13 years, so it‚Äôs part of how I think. For anyone familiar with ‚ÄúPartWorks‚Äù that used to ship with ShopBots, it‚Äôs the same software.

Vectric‚Äôs software is essentially a glorified vector drawing program, and it‚Äôs designed primarily for sign makers. This makes it easy to get started, but causes problems down the line. I think a lot of their problems would be solved if the two major steps were divided into slightly different interfaces: split ‚Äúarrange vectors in your material‚Äù from ‚Äúselect which vectors to use as the sources for toolpaths‚Äù.

I‚Äôm perhaps a bit too harsh saying ‚Äúglorified vector drawing program‚Äù; most of the tools work in actual numerical dimensions. You get a coordinate system with an offset and working area. For the polyline tool, you can pick a start point using coordinates and type in dX and dY for line segments, and you can move vectors to positions using those coordinates. Trim, join, polygon, circle, fillet, etc‚Ä¶ It‚Äôs pretty close to old-school AutoCAD in most respects, minus the command line.

If you make a template for your entire machine bed, you can put in your workholding holes, fixtures, etc‚Ä¶and see (and modify) the entire thing at a glance. I find this particularly important for resuming jobs; you don‚Äôt have to write down an origin offset for each part, provided your machine re-homes within tolerances. Furthermore, if you have a bunch of sheets of material that you‚Äôre chewing through gradually, make a file for each and you can see the already-used material when placing new parts. The caveat is, the program won‚Äôt helpfully remind you when you try to mill through a hold-down screw or use reuse material that‚Äôs already gone.

If you need to make some basic shapes, add a mounting hole, or similar, you can do it right from the drawing tools. We have a standard set of ‚Äúnew sheet workholding holes‚Äù that were constructed this way, plus a standard pattern of spoilboard holes.

It can do corner reliefs (dogbone fillets, T-bone fillets) in the drawing tools, though you have to remember to add them, and you have to set the radius manually.

Tabs have plenty of options, and can be placed in the GUI, or semi-automated.

If you want to duplicate a group of vectors, it lets you spec the edge-to-edge gap, which I love (make the computer do the computer work). I believe it also copies things like custom tab locations when you do that.

There‚Äôs no adaptive clearing, so your parts aren‚Äôt going to be machined as quickly as if you have it. The pocket tool does offset or raster clearing, with a depth-per-pass and a stepover percentage. You may find yourself doing more cutouts for large pockets than milling inner pockets into chips as a result, which is kind of a pain. Hence‚Ä¶tabs.

There‚Äôs no concept of a ‚Äúpart‚Äù as a collection of vectors in the software, at least not in the artboard; if you accidentally shift one hole or the part outline, you‚Äôre going to end up with scrap. Note that the arrow keys are one way to move vectors, and they do it quietly for whatever is selected. You can mitigate this by grouping all of the features of a part immediately after import, placing it, then ungrouping before generating toolpaths, but it‚Äôs a worse experience than if there were the concept of a part. There is the concept of a part when running toolpaths; you can have it cut all of the vectors inside a part, then move onto the next one. I haven‚Äôt used this much; I think you need to set it after you generate toolpaths the conventional way. Again, I think it would help greatly if there were a ‚Äúmove stuff around‚Äù mode and a separate ‚Äúchoose vectors for toolpaths‚Äù mode.

The same goes for scaling: it‚Äôs pretty easy to scale things, but as a result, it‚Äôs easy to scale things accidentally too.

If you‚Äôre not great with a mouse, or aren‚Äôt experienced with selection tools, it can be painfully slow to set up a part with lots of cutouts or holes. It helps greatly to learn inclusive and exclusive selection are triggered by dragging left and right in the rectangular selection tool. See above too, though ‚Äì if you mess up and move everything over‚Ä¶

If you‚Äôre doing 2.5D machining, you need to enter all of your cut depths manually; parts are going to be coming in as 2D vectors only. This can make the process more error-prone. Each cut depth gets its own toolpath, which leads to strange cut ordering and clutter too. If you have overlapping edges in 2.5D parts, that‚Äôs where it can get very complicated and frustrating ‚Äì you can end up cutting air a lot of the time, or leaving thin foil in places. On the rare occasions we do this, it‚Äôs usually a lot of custom work with the drawing tools ‚Äì polylines, rectangles, trimming, joining, layerswapping. I used to do this a lot more for personal projects at a makerspace; most of the team parts are straight 2D, so we don‚Äôt deal with this often.

There is a concept of layers, which allows you to preserve your selections of vectors ‚Äì e.g., put all of the small/mounting holes on one layer so you can return to them later when you generate a toolpath to cut them.

More complex vectors (e.g., outer profile of a part) will often come in as unconnected pieces and need to be joined into a loop with one of the drawing tools. The joining tool is semi-automated, and you can usually just select all of the vectors in a part and run it ‚Äì it‚Äôll ignore anything with a gap greater than the tolerance, including separate closed vectors. This usually works fine, but if you have two edges on top of each other, it can require some extra work (trimming or manual selection) to fix.

There is a tool library, and it is pretty quick to set up new tools (compared to CAM software designed for, say, a VMC). Want to add a new endmill? Give it the cutting diameter, cutting speeds, spindle speed, stepover, depth-per-pass, and you‚Äôre good to go. A few versions ago, they even added the ability to set up tools per material. The bad news is, the library isn‚Äôt protected super well; you can accidentally change the library tool settings instead of overriding for just a particular toolpath.

Creating toolpaths is pretty straightforward for simple parts; select the vectors to cut, click the button to create the path, then click Generate at the bottom. But it gets tedious pretty quickly. For the most part, I want the same two to four toolpaths every time: small holes (i.e., smaller than 2x endmill diameter), big holes/pockets, large inner cutouts, and outer profiles. Instead of going through and creating these each time, I put one of each in the template. Before figuring this out, I had a few jobs where I cut on the outside of the small holes, or the inside of the outer profiles. Also, lead-ins, lead-outs, ramps, and other details differ between the small holes and outer profiles, so it helps to have those saved.

Turning off the ‚Äúswitch to 3D preview after generating toolpaths‚Äù option (paraphrasing here) helps with the flow, but also gets rid of the biggest indication that you‚Äôve actually clicked the Generate button. You can look for the ‚Äúthis is the path the centerline of the tool will take while cutting‚Äù lines, but sometimes you have to zoom in for that to be visible.

When you click on an already-saved toolpath, it nukes whatever vector selection you had on the artboard and replaces it with whatever was selected for generation last time (which is sometimes nothing, if it‚Äôs a new path). Again, not too bad if you have a part with 3 holes, but awful if you just spent 5 minutes painstakingly selecting every small hole in the batch of 10 gussets you were about to cut. This is part of why I use the layers ‚Äì move vectors representing small holes/large holes/outer profiles to their respective layer first, then use each layer to select all the vectors for a toolpath. It‚Äôs too bad toolpaths can‚Äôt be set up to pull from a layer automatically, because selecting all vectors on a certain layer is an extra step to remember and takes extra clicks.

Exporting toolpaths isn‚Äôt super goof-proof. The default is ‚Äúexport what is highlighted in the toolpaths list‚Äù. My preferred setting is ‚Äúexport all visible toolpaths to a single file‚Äù, and to use the visibility checkboxes to choose. This makes the setting less transient (i.e., you won‚Äôt undo it by clicking on the list somewhere). The caveat, of course, is that sometimes you accidentally export or even just run your hold-down holes twice and plunge right into a screw. My strategy for avoiding it is to export all toolpaths before starting any of them, and to number the files in the order to be run.

If you guys use Solidworks I highly recommend SolidCAM, if you use Inventor or Onshape I would investigate Fusion or Onshape CAM when it releases fully

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2025-02-14T18:29:21.878Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":174,"readers_count":173,"score":44.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":491502,"topic_slug":"hsmworks-is-ending-alternatives","display_username":"Mike Marandola","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":11375,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"1983N11"},"post_url":"/t/hsmworks-is-ending-alternatives/491502/5","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3527255,"name":"Alex Weiss","username":"AlexW","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/b5a626/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-14T18:32:31.113Z","cooked":"

Personally I found Fusion 360 CAM to work great, both for the CNC router and CNC mill the team had. Helped that there was no need to leave the software to do CAD and then the CAM.

I‚Äôm an alumni now at RPI and on a FSAE Racecar team where I generally use mastercam but I understand not many FRC teams have access. MasterCam has pretty much anything you could ever need.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2025-02-14T18:32:45.133Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":171,"readers_count":170,"score":54.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":491502,"topic_slug":"hsmworks-is-ending-alternatives","display_username":"Alex Weiss","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":11375,"username":"Mike_Marandola","name":"Mike Marandola","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mike_marandola/{size}/255213_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":71618,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/hsmworks-is-ending-alternatives/491502/6","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3527264,"name":"Ronnie Sherrer","username":"RonnieS","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ronnies/{size}/198714_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-14T18:38:09.960Z","cooked":"

My understanding is that this is coinciding with them also launching F360 as ITAR compliant. This makes sense as Autodesk has to pay solidworks for HSMwork.

As a team, we use F360 and HSMworks. We will be moving to only F360.

For work, I use PowerMill, F360, Solidworks CAM, and HSMworks. All at pretty good. F360 keeps getting better and really is a really good platform for keeping fixture setups, tool library, job setups, etc. I am not sure why you wouldn‚Äôt want to use F360.

Solidworks CAM is also fine for most stuff you would do for FRC as long as they have a post or you edit one to work with your machine setup.

I have wanted to play with SolidCAM for awhile now but haven‚Äôt felt the need to. This might push the ‚Äúgo play with it‚Äù button to see how it is.

-Ronnie

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2025-02-14T18:38:09.960Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":166,"readers_count":165,"score":63.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":491502,"topic_slug":"hsmworks-is-ending-alternatives","display_username":"Ronnie Sherrer","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":19943,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Engineer/part-time coach "},"post_url":"/t/hsmworks-is-ending-alternatives/491502/7","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3527316,"name":"Stephen Mills","username":"smills","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/a88e57/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-14T19:31:02.011Z","cooked":"
sanddrag:

‚Ä¶Anyone try CAM Workbench in FreeCAD? How is it these days? I‚Äôve heard they‚Äôve made a ton of improvements lately‚Ä¶

FreeCAD is what I‚Äôve used for all the cnc‚Äôd parts for our team for a few years. It‚Äôs been more than adequate for the simple 2.5D work that‚Äôs needed for FRC parts. The only significant recent change for this workbench is the re-name. It was called the ‚Äúpath‚Äù workbench prior to the big 1.0 release and now it‚Äôs called the ‚ÄúCAM‚Äù workbench.

There‚Äôs the usual hassle of exporting from your design program and importing for CAM, but feature wise it‚Äôs pretty good. You can do adaptive clearing operations and add ‚Äúdress-ups‚Äù to your operations to do lead in/out and add holding tabs.

It could use improvement in selection work flow and the tool definition seems quirky to me, but since it is free and open source software you don‚Äôt have worries about losing access to the program.

I‚Äôm eager to hear if anyone else actually uses it. Sometimes it seems I‚Äôm the only one.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2025-02-14T19:31:02.011Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":154,"readers_count":153,"score":50.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":491502,"topic_slug":"hsmworks-is-ending-alternatives","display_username":"Stephen Mills","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":39194,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"6026 Lead Mentor / Drive Coach"},"post_url":"/t/hsmworks-is-ending-alternatives/491502/8","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3571012,"name":"sanddrag","username":"sanddrag","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/c68b51/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-28T06:39:06.756Z","cooked":"

I decided to give FreeCAD a try. I‚Äôm struggling with units. Do you work in millimeters or inches? For inches, I‚Äôm finding it super annoying to have to type a double quote mark after every numerical input.

I also find the model rotating to feel pretty odd compared to Solidworks, Onshape, or Inventor. Do you feel the same?

Just as an update, if you are using HSMWorks through an educational license, the expiration is unfortunately far sooner than 2028. Noticed our educational license expired last week and was informed the below by Autodesk Education Support this afternoon when inquiring how to get it renewed.

As promised, I contacted the senior team, and I would like to inform you that as part of Autodesk‚Äôs recent changes to our product offerings, HSMWorks is no longer included under the free educational license program. This means that renewals using an educational license are no longer supported for this product.

It seems we will have to figure out an alternative earlier then we at least previously thought. One of our other mentors license does not expire until July so we are at least covered for the near-term, but it‚Äôs unfortunate that it was removed from the educational offerings.

sanddrag:

I think Onshape is working on CAM

I participated in their Early Visibility Program for CAM Studio. Honestly, had a terrible experience. Since then, it has improved slightly, but I would still consider it unintuitive and basically unusable.

Onshape for CAD, and Fusion for CAM, at both work and robotics‚Ä¶for now.
